title: Shiny Feature vs Refactor
description: The PM wants a shiny new feature in this sprint. You see a refactor that would remove ~20% of user bugs, but it would take the same two weeks as the feature.

choices.text: Push to do the refactor first, using bug data and long-term impact to argue for it.
Ship the feature now, but clearly log the refactor as a must-do item for the next sprint.
Try to do both this sprint by working extra hours and taking the load yourself.

title: One Small Feature?
description: Mid-sprint, the founder asks for 'one small feature' in the current release. It's actually big and would require rethinking part of your solution, and the team is already stretched.

choices.text: Push back firmly and spell out the engineering impact and risks.
Say yes and cut corners so it fits, even if the code quality suffers.
Suggest a minimal version that fits the current architecture and has a clear upgrade path later.

title: Junior on the Critical Path
description: A junior engineer is stuck on a legacy database migration. The deadline is close and this work is on the critical path.

choices.text: Take the task over yourself to make sure it ships on time.
Pair with them, unblock the work, and use it as coaching time.
Give them a quick hint and leave them to figure out the rest.

title: Two-Week Miracle?
description: The founder promises a client a feature in two weeks. You know it needs at least two months. Do you:

choices.text: Say nothing and work extra hours to meet the deadline.
Push back immediately, explaining the risks of rushing.
Negotiate a scope reduction to meet the deadline.

title: Surprise! You're in Sales Now
description: The founder pings: 'Can you jump on 3 customer calls today? We need someone technical.' Your calendar was supposed to be focus time.

choices.text: Say no and offer a better plan: a quick FAQ and only joining real deep-dives.
Say yes instantly and spend the day as surprise sales engineer.
Take the calls, but frame it as a one-off and pitch a proper rotation + escalation path.

title: Done Early, Now What?
description: You finished all your sprint tickets in half the estimated time. There are still several days left in the sprint, and no one has noticed yet.

choices.text: Tell the team you're free and jump in where someone is blocked.
Keep quiet and treat it as bonus chill / learning time.
Secretly improve something important (tests, CI, monitoring), gather data, then pitch it as a win.

title: This Feature Is Fighting Back
description: You're stuck on a hard part of a feature and you're pretty sure you won't meet the deadline unless something changes.

choices.text: Say nothing for now and try to figure it out solo; only explain the miss after it's clearly impossible.
Inform the founder ASAP with the reason and present options (reduce scope, move deadline, or get help).
Ask a teammate to pair and research known issues (docs, GitHub issues, forums), then report back with what you found.
